column103: There has been so much growth in the cloud native space and so many more projects in CNCF now - it feels like it's time for a step back to evaluate top-down what the goals of the foundation are and how things like sandbox, incubation, etc really work to serve those goals. For a project like gRPC to be held up in incubation despite being actively used in production at many large enterprises feels off. Understanding the TOC has their metrics they're looking for in marking a project as "graduated"; not sure that designation is sending the right message to the end user though.

column101: We are super busy maintaining the projects - often times, we do not have the cycles to initiate outbound requests for marketing (let alone the time to brainstorm opportunities etc).    In general, my experience with the CNCF has been that it's pretty passive. To get things to happen, I first need to know that they should be happening, and then I need to take initiative to engage CNCF and follow through. I'd really love to see this turned the other way around - CNCF to reach out to us and see how things are going, what CNCF can do to help with specific things... this includes marketing (e.g. the marketing check-in may ask what our last X events were, if we're planning more, if we've had time to tweet or blog recently, etc).
column102: I'd love to see a hosted system for opt-in usage reporting. It can be really hard to know about project adoption and feature usage without some sort of instrumentation

column103: The onboarding process is pretty good - the checklist and support is very much appreciated. There are some small tweaks and TLC needed in some docs.    The process didn't have a deadline. In my experience at least a soft deadline is helpful in calling out expectations. Consider a deadline range e.g. 4-12 weeks or something along those lines. You can use language to get the point across that it's not the end of the world if go over the max timeframe, just that a best effort should be made to try to complete onboarding within the timeframe.

column74: Yes, and my needs were generally met
column93: The LF/CNCF staff do a wonderful job. They are responsive and helpful.    To be part of the CNCF takes on other elements including dealing with the CNCF TOC. The TOC is scoped with the technical direction of the CNCF. To help with that they have created SIGs. Sometimes SIGs are helpful, such as recent work on governance and contributor experience by experienced professions. Other times the SIGs add work to CNCF projects and even do things that add more work to CNCF projects. All of this SIG work is mostly without TOC oversight.    Projects that come into the CNCF need to have the time and ability to work in this structure. Maintainers need to have time to attend meetings, engage, and sometimes tell SIG chairs no. Like when SIG chairs try to tell maintainers to make changes to their projects that aren't TOC requirements for anything (I've seen this happen). Not every maintainer has this time or has a personality that can tell A type personalities no.    So, I would recommend the CNCF to certain types of maintainers who can use the benefits while being able to deal with some of the negative aspects.    This has gotten better in recent months but still has room for improvement before I would tell anyone to use the CNCF.
column97: The landscape is valuable in finding projects but not valuable in deciding which projects are good to use. Figuring that out is a hard problem because few provide people guidance on how to make good decisions for themselves.
column99: The Tech Radar is great because it provides end-users with details on what other end-users think. This is instead of vendors who have a motive to push their own things.    This is also valuable to projects because they can see what end users are using with some insight into why.
